function_call.name: classify_risks_PESTLE
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Lack of statistically significant relationship between natural environment and prevalence of obesity","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Correlation between black population and higher prevalence of obesity in a non-linear fashion","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Heterogeneity in the associations of low-income and high education with prevalence of obesity","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Association between residential density and covid-19 fatality rates","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Indirect correlation between regional auto centrality index and covid-19 mortality through obesity influence","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Indirect association between pedestrian links per square mile and covid-19 mortality rate through street connectivity","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Heterogeneity in the indirect effects of residential density on covid-19 risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Heterogeneous patterns in the indirect effects of auto-oriented accessibility and street connectivity on covid-19 mortality","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Failure to consider smaller areas immediately around where people live and are exposed may limit the accuracy of the findings.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Exclusion of potentially important variables such as air pollution and wind speed may lead to incomplete understanding of covid-19 spread.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Inability to make causal inferences due to the correlational nature of the study may limit the ability to identify direct causes of covid-19 mortality rates.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Study documents how chronic disease and covid-19 are related to the built and natural environment, potentially indicating environmental factors that contribute to disease spread.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Authors express caution in drawing conclusions based on fixed parameter methods and highly aggregate spatial data, highlighting the potential for inaccurate conclusions.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Authors express
